Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Impact of Storm Activity on Recent Changes in Arctic Sea Ice Mass Balance
Award.AbstractNarration: This project is to investigate impacts of changes in storm track dynamics on the recent rapid reduction in Arctic sea ice extent and volume. The increase of storm intensity and frequency result in enhanced high-frequency synoptic-scale variations and feedbacks in the Arctic climate system, and may make an integrative contribution to the basin-wide sea ice reduction. The project studies build upon previous work, and combine model simulations with satellite products and in situ observations to integrate and delineate physical causes of sea-ice mass balance changes in the context of storm-induced air-ice-sea interactions. This research will bridge synoptic-scale weather activities and large-scale climate variability and changes. The expected outcome includes assembled schematics linking storm-induced synoptic-scale variation with recently observed rapid loss of Arctic sea ice mass. Changes in sea ice concentration/extent, thickness/volume, and heat budget terms at the air-ice-sea interface that follow the motion of identified storms will be compiled. The project also has important broader impacts across the scientific community and in the general public. A Ph.D. graduate student will be trained to join the next generation of climate researchers. The project outcome will be integrated into graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 student lectures, and aid policymakers to make wiser and more economical decisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapid ongoing sea ice shrinking in the Arctic Ocean is one of the most evident indicators of the Arctic climate change that is most sensitive to the global climate change due to its unique environmental characteristics, i.e., snow and ice covering most of the Arctic region as an important and large part of the global Cryosphere. However, the causes of Arctic sea ice retreat and its trends are not known well and under debate.  This collaborative project focused on understanding how the atmosphere drives the recently observed acceleration of Arctic sea ice mass balance change through satellite observations and numerical model simulations. The work done at University of Wisconsin-Madison focused on using historical and current satellite data to retrieve sea ice information, generate satellite based data products with high Climate Data Record (CDR) quality, apply those satellite based data products to study Arctic sea ice change associated with global climate change, and provide the basic and critical actual data for numerical model initial conditions and data assimilation as well as interested researchers and general public.  The work done at the lead-institute of this collaborative project at University of Alaska-Fairbanks will be reported separately.

Upon this award support, there are two product suites being generated for the Climate Data Record (CDR) quality data products and climate change study for both Arctic and Antarctic regions. One is called the “AVHRR Polar Pathfinder (APP)”. The standard 5 km APP product suite was later enhanced to include cloud properties, surface temperature and albedo, radiative fluxes, and sea ice properties in reduced spatial resolution of 25 km. The extended APP product suite is called “APP-x”. The APP and APP-x data products, their processing codes, and algorithm documentations can all be accessed and downloaded from National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) at the websites of http://gis.ncdc.noaa.gov/geoportal/catalog/search /resource/details.page?id=gov.noaa.ncdc:C00940  and http://gis.ncdc.noaa.gov/geoportal/ catalog/search/resource/details.page?id=gov.noaa.ncdc:C00941 by any researcher and general public as well.

Using the APP-x product suite, it is first time that the Arctic climate trend study reveals that Arctic sea ice has been declining in terms of sea ice extent/coverage, thickness, and volume over the period of 1982~2015 in both warm and cold seasons represented by September and April. The Arctic ice extent/coverage has been decreasing at the rate of 1.47x106 km2 per decade, ice thickness has been thinning at the rate of 1.7 cm per decade, and correspondingly the Arctic has been losing its ice at the rate of 1693 km3 per decade in September. In April, those values are 1.26x106 km2 per decade, 4.6 cm per decade, and 4193 km3 per decade for Arctic sea ice extent/coverage, thickness, and volume, respectively. In addition, one of the first applications of APP-x led to the discovery that, over the period 1982–1999, the Arctic warmed and became cloudier in spring and summer, but cooled and became less cloudy in winter over the central Arctic Ocean, Greenland Sea, Norwegian Sea, and Barents Sea. The implication was that if seasonal cloud amounts did not change the way they had, surface warming would have been even greater than what was observed. In contrast, the recent extension of APP-x through 2015 shows that the central Arctic Ocean has warmed significantly over the last 1.5 decades such that the overall effect for 1982-2015 is winter warming rather than cooling, with a weak cooling in the Siberian region. It was demonstrated that changes in ice concentration and cloud cover played major roles in the magnitude of Arctic surface temperature trends. Significant surface warming associated with sea ice loss accounted for most of the observed warming trend in autumn. In winter, cloud cover trends explain most of the surface temperature cooling. In spring, half of the warming is attributed to the trend in cloud cover.
